credits.writtenBy: Michael Curtis and Gregory S. Malins

content.description: Central Perk, Chandler and Rachel are sitting on the couch.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Eh…, I don’t, I don’t know.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Well, as old as he is in dog years, do you think Snoopy should still be allowed to fly this thing?

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Rachel?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Do you remember when you first came here, how you spent two weeks getting trained by another waitress?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Oh, sure! Do you need me to train somebody new?

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Good one. Actually, ah, Terry wants you to take the training again, whenever.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Eh, do you believe that?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yeah?

content.description: The hallway of Ross’s building, there is a Brown Bird girl selling cookies, as Ross and Chandler come up the stairs.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: So that’s two boxes of the Holiday Macaroons. On behalf of the Brown Birds of America, I salute you. (Does the Brown Bird salute, she blows on a bird call, then holds her hand, palm facing out, next to her face, and then waves it like a bird flapping it’s wings.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Just admit it Chandler, you have no backhand.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Excuse me little one, I have a very solid backhand.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Shielding your face and shrieking like a girl… is not a backhand.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I was shrieking… like a Marine.
(they both start up the stairs.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: All right here. Watch me execute the three ‘P’s of championship play. Power. (swings the racquet) Precision. (swings the racquet.) and penache. (does a backswing and hits Sarah who’s started up the stairs, knocking her down, they both watch in horror.)

content.description: Central Perk, the gang’s all there discussing the incident.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: You broke a little girl’s leg?!!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I know. I feel horrible. Okay.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Says here that a muppet got whacked on Seasame Street last night. (to Ross) Where exactly were around ten-ish?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well, I’m gonna go see her. I want to bring her something, what do you think she’ll like?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Maybe a Hello Kitty doll, the ability to walk…
(Rachel starts to laugh, and Ross notices her.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I’m gonna get back to retraining. (gets up)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: All right, see you guys. (starts to leave)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Look out kids, he’s coming! (Ross continues to leave with his head down in shame.)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: And I gotta go sell some Christmas trees.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Have fun. Oh wait, no, don’t! I forgot I am totally against that now.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: What? Me having a job?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: No, no, I am against innocent trees being cut down in their prime, and their, their corpses grotesquely dressed in like tinsel and twinkly lights. (to Joey) Hey, how do you sleep at night?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well, I’m pretty tired from lugging the trees around all day. Hey, Phoebe listen, you got this all wrong. Those trees were born to be Christmas trees, their fulfilling their life purpose, by, by making people happy.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Really?
(Phoebe turns and looks at Monica, while Joey frantically motions to Chandler to help him out.)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yes. Yes, and ah, ah, the trees are happy too, because for most of them, it’s the only chance to see New York.
[cut to Gunther retraining Rachel.]

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: …and after you’ve delivered the drinks, you take the empty tray…

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Gunther, Gunther, please, I’ve worked here for two and a half years, I know the empty trays go over there. (points to the counter.)

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: What if you put them here. (sets the empty tray on another stack of empty trays on the back counter.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Huh. Well, y’know that’s actually a really good idea, because that way they’ll be closer to the mugs. Y’know what, you should have the other waitresses do that too.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: They already do. That’s why they call it the ‘tray spot.’

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Gee, I always heard them talk about that, I just always thought that it was a club they went to. Oh God, I’m, I’m sorry. (walks away)

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: It’s all right. Sweetheart.

content.description: Sarah’s bedroom, her room is decorated with a space motif.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: So, this must be kinda neat for ya, huh? I mean, your Dad tells me that you get a couple of days off school, and you, you ah, don’t have to sell those cookies anymore.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Well, I kinda wanted to sell the cookies. The girl who sells the most wins a trip to Spacecamp, and gets to sit in a real space shuttle.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Wow, you ah, you really like all this space stuff, huh?

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Yeah. My Dad says if I spend as much time helping him clean apartments, as I do daydreaming about outer space, he’d be able to afford a trip to the Taj Mahal.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I think you would have to clean a whole lot of apartments to go all the way to India.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: No. The one in Atlantic City, Dad loves the slots. He says he’s gonna double the college money my Grandma left me.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Huh. Well, good luck to Dad. Say, how many more boxes would you have to sell in order to win?

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: The girl who won last year sold four hundred and seventy-five.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Yeah.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: So far, I’ve sold seventy-five.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Four hundred, huh? Well, that sounds do-able. (starts to get out his wallet) How much are the boxes?

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Five dollars a box.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: And what is second prize?

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: A ten speed bike. But, I’d rather have something my Dad couldn’t sell.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well, that makes sense.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Could you do me one favor, if it’s not too much trouble?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Yeah, Sarah, anything.

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Could you pull open the curtains for me? The astronauts from the space shuttle are gonna be on the news, and since we don’t have a TV, the lady across the alley said she’d push hers up to a window, so I could watch it.

content.description: A hallway, Ross is selling Brown Bird cookies for Sarah, he stops and knocks on a door.

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: Yesss?
content.parenthetical: looking through her peephole, we see Ross standing in the hallway.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hi, I’m selling Brown Bird cookies.

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: You’re no Brown Bird, I can see you through my peephole.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: No, hi, I’m, I’m an honorary Brown Bird (does the Brown Bird salute.)

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: What does that mean?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ah, well, it means that I can sell cookies, but I’m not invited to sleep-overs.

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: I can dial 9-1-1 at the touch of a button, y’know. Now, go away!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: No, please, please, um, it’s for a poor little girl who wants to go to Spacecamp more than anything in the world.

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: I’m pressing, a policeman is on his way.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay, okay! I’m going. I’m going. (goes across the hall to knock on another door.)

content.speaker: Woman
content.text: I can still see you!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: All right!!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Hey.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey. What, what are you doing here?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Well, I-I thought a lot about what you said, and um, I realilized duh, all right maybe I was a little judgmental. Yeah, (looks at the tree) oh, but oh…

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Look now, Phoebe remember, hey, their just fulfilling their Christmas…

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Destiny.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Sure.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Yes.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: All right.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Okay. (One of Joey’s co-workers, walks by with a dead tree.) Yikes! That one doesn’t look very fulfilled.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Oh, that’s, that’s ah, one of the old ones, he’s just taking it to the back.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: You keep the old ones in the back, that is so ageist.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well we have to make room for the fresh ones.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: So, what happens to the old guys?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well, they go into the chipper.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Why, do I have a feeling that’s not as happy as it sounds? (Joey points out one going into the chipper to her, as this haunty, demonic music starts to play in the background) No! Nooooo!!! (she winces in horror and hides her face against Joey’s shoulder, as she sees the tree spit out from the chipper.)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey! Hey!! (makes the ‘cut it’ motion with his hands)
content.parenthetical: to the guy operating the chipper

content.description: Central Perk, all except Phoebe are there, Ross is telling the gang, minus Rachel who’s still being retrained, about the different cookie options.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: …and these come in the shapes of your favourite Christmas characters, Santa, Rudolph, and Baby Jesus.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: All right, I’ll take a box of the cream filled Jesus’s.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Wait a minute, one box! Come on, I’m trying to send a little girl to Spacecamp, I’m putting you down for five boxes. Chandler, what about you?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Ahh, do you have any coconut flavoured deities?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: No, but ah, there’s coconut in the Hanukkah Menoreoes. I tell you what, I’ll put you down for eight boxes, one for each night.
(Chandler mouths ‘Okay.’)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Mon?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: All right, I’ll take one box of the mint treasures, just one, and that’s it. I-I started gaining weight after I joined the Brown Birds. (to Ross) Remember, how Dad bought all my boxes and I ate them all?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ah, no Mon, Dad had to buy everyone of your boxes because you ate them all. But ah, y’know I’m sure that’s not gonna happen this time, why don’t I put you down for three of the mint treasures and just a couple of the Rudolph’s.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh, come on, now you know you want ‘em.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Don’t, don’t, don’t, don’t, don’t do this.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I’ll tell you what Mon, I’ll give you the first box for free.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh God! I gotta go! (runs out)
content.parenthetical: she reaches out for it and stops

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Come on! All the cool kids are eating ‘em! (chases after her.)
[cut to Gunther retraining Rachel.]

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: And when you have a second later, I wanna show you why we don’t just trap spiders under coffee mugs and leave them there.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I’m training to be better at a job that I hate, my life officially sucks.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Look Rach, wasn’t this supposed to a temporary thing? I thought you wanted to do fashion stuff?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well, yeah! I’m still pursuing that.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: How… exactly are you pursuing that? Y’know other than sending out resumes like what, two years ago?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well, I’m also sending out… good thoughts.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: If you ask me, as long as you got this job, you’ve got nothing pushing you to get another one. You need the fear.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: The fear?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: He’s right, if you quit this job, you then have motivation to go after a job you really want.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well then how come you’re still at a job that you hate, I mean why don’t you quit and get ‘the fear’?
(Chandler and Joey both laugh)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Because, I’m too afraid.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I don’t know, I mean I would give anything to work for a designer, y’know, or a buyer… Oh, I just don’t want to be 30 and still work here.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yeah, that’d be much worse than being 28, and still working here.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Rachel?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: Remind me to review with you which pot is decaf and which is regular.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Can’t I just look at the handles on them?

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: You would think.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay, fine. Gunther, y’know what, I am a terrible waitress, do you know why I’m a terrible waitress? Because, I don’t care. I don’t care. I don’t care which pot is regular and which pot is decaf, I don’t care where the tray spot is, I just don’t care, this is not what I want to do. So I don’t think I should do it anymore. I’m gonna give you my weeks notice.

content.speaker: Gunther
content.text: What?!

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Gunther, I quit.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Does this mean we’re gonna have to start paying for coffee? (Joey shrugs his shoulders.)

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, Chandler is entering numbers on a calculator as Ross reads off how much he’s sold.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: …and 12, 22, 18, four… (Chandler starts laughing) What?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I spelled out boobies.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Ross, but me down for another box of the mint treasures, okay. Where, where are the mint treasures?
content.parenthetical: comes up and starts looking through Ross’s cookie supply

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ah, we’re out. I sold them all.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Monica, I’m cutting you off.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: No. No, just, just, just a couple more boxes. It-it-it’s no big deal, all right, I’m-I’m cool. You gotta help me out with a couple more boxes!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Mon, look at yourself. You have cookie on your neck.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh God! (runs to the bathroom)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: So, how many have you sold so far?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Check this out. Five hundred and seventeen boxes!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Oh my God, how did you do that?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Okay, the other night I was leaving the museum just as ‘Laser Floyd’ was letting out of the planetarium, without even trying I sold 50 boxes! That’s when it occurred to me, the key to my success, ‘the munchies.’ So I ah, started hitting the NYU dorms around midnight. I am selling cookies by the case. They call me: ‘Cookie Dude!’

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Okay, stop what you’re doing, I need envelope stuffers, I need stamp lickers…

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well hey, who did these resumes for ya?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Me! On my computer.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well you sure used a large font.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Eh, yeah, well ah, waitress at a coffee shop and cheer squad co-captain only took up so much room.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Hey-hey-hey that’s funny! Your funny Chandler! Your a funny guy! You wanna know what else is really funny?!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Something else I might have said?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I don’t know, I don’t know, weren’t you the guy that told me to quit my job when I had absolutely nothing else to do. Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha!!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Sweetie, calm down, it’s gonna be okay.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: No, it’s not gonna be okay Ross, tomorrow is my last day, and I don’t have a lead. Okay, y’know what, I’m just gonna, I’m just gonna call Gunther and I’m gonna tell him, I’m not quitting.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You-you-you don’t wanna give into the fear.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You and your stupid fear. I hate your fear. I would like to take you and your fear…

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey! I got great news!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Run, Joey! Run for your life! (runs out)

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: What? Rachel, listen, have you ever heard of Fortunata Fashions?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well my old man is doing a plumbing job down there and he heard they have an opening. So, you want me to see if I can get you an interview?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Oh my God! Yes, I would love that, oh, that is soo sweet, Joey.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Not a problem.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Thanks.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: And now for the great news.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: What, that wasn’t the great news?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Only if you think it’s better than this… (holds up an aerosol can) snow-in-a-can!! I got it at work. Mon, you want me to decorate the window, give it a kind of Christmas lookie.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Christmas cookie?

content.description: Joey work, Joey is showing a guy a tree.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Okay, and ah, this one here is a Douglas Fir, now it’s a little more money, but you get a nicer smell.

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: Looks good. I’ll take it.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait! No, no, you don’t want that one. No, you can have this cool brown one. (points to the almost dead tree she has)

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: It’s-it’s-it’s almost dead!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Okay but that’s why you have to buy it, so it can fulfil it’s Christmas destiny, otherwise there gonna throw it into the chipper. Tell him, Joey

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Yeah, the ah, trees that don’t fulfil their Christmas destiny are thrown in the chipper.

content.speaker: Guy
content.text: I-I think I’m gonna look around a little bit more.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Pheebs, you gotta stop this, I working on commission here.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Hey, guys. I’m here to pick out my Christmas tree.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Well look no further, (shows her the dead one) this one’s yours! Ahhh.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Is this the one that I threw out last year?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: All right y’know what, nevermind! Everyone wants to have a green one! I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to get so emotional, I guess it’s just the holidays, it’s hard.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh honey, is that ‘cause your Mom died around Christmas?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, I wasn’t even thinking about that.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh. (turns and looks at Joey, who gives a ‘way-to-go’ thumbs up and smile.)

content.description: A Brown Bird meeting, Ross is there with the other Brown Birds to see who won the contest.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hi there. How many, how many ah, did you sell?
content.parenthetical: to the girl sitting next to him

content.speaker: Girl
content.text: I’m not gonna tell you! You’re the bad man who broke Sarah’s leg.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hey now! That was an accident, okay.

content.speaker: Girl
content.text: You’re a big scrud.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: What’s a scrud?

content.speaker: Girl
content.text: Why don’t you look in the mirror, scrud.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I don’t have too. I can just look at you.

content.speaker: Leader
content.text: All right girls, and man. Let’s see your final tallies. (all the girls raise their hands) Ohhhh, Debbie, (looks at her form) 321 boxes of cookies, (to Debbie) Very nice.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Not nice enough.

content.speaker: Leader
content.text: Charla, 278. Sorry, dear, but still good.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Good for a scrud.

content.speaker: Leader
content.text: Oh, yes Elizabeth. Ah, 871.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: That’s crap!! Sister Brown Bird. (to Elizabeth) Good going. (does the salute)

content.speaker: Leader
content.text: Who’s next? (goes over and stands behind Ross, who’s feverishly writing on his form, and clears her throat to get his attention.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Hi there!

content.speaker: Leader
content.text: Hi. And batting for Sarah, Ross Geller, 872. Although, it looks like you bought an awful lot of cookies yourself.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Um, that is because my doctor says that I have a very serious… nuget… diffency.

content.description: Central Perk, Chandler, Phoebe, and Ross are there.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Tell us what happened, Brown Bird Ross.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well, I lost. Some little girl loaned her uniform to her nineteen year old sister, who went down to the U.S.S. Nimitz, and sold over 2,000 boxes.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hey! How’d the interview go?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Oh, I blew it. I wouldn’t of even hired me.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh, come here sweetie, listen, you’re gonna go on like a thousand interviews before you get a job. (she glares at him) That’s not how that was supposed to come out.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: This is the worst Christmas ever.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Y’know what Rach, maybe you should just, y’know stay here at the coffee house.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I can’t! It’s too late! Terry already hired that girl over there. (points to her) Look at her, she’s even got waitress experience. Last night she was teaching everybody how to make napkin… (starts to cry) swans.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: That word was swans.

content.description: The hallway between the two apartments, Chandler, Phoebe, Ross, and Rachel are coming up the stairs.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Well seeing that drunk Santa wet himself, really perked up my Christmas.
(They start to go into Monica and Rachel’s, their apartment is filled with all of the old Christmas trees from Joey’s work.)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh! Oh my God!

content.speaker: Joey and Monica
content.text: Merry Christmas!!
content.parenthetical: jumping up from behind the couch

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: You saved them! You guys! Oh God, you’re the best!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: It’s like ‘Night of the Living Dead Christmas Trees.’
(phone rings)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Hello? (listens) Yeah, this is she. (listens) Oh! You’re kidding! You’re kidding! (listens) Oh thank you! I love you!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Sure, everybody loves a kidder.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I got the job!

content.speaker: All
content.text: That’s great! Hey! Excellent!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Oh, God bless us, everyone.

content.description: Central Perk, Rachel is serving her last cup of coffee.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Here we go. I’m serving my last cup of coffee. (the gang starts humming the graduation theme) There you go. (hands it to Chandler) Enjoy. (they all cheer)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Should I tell her I ordered tea?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Um, excuse me, everyone. Ah, this is my last night working here, and I ah, just wanted say that I made some really good friends working here, and ah, it’s just time to move on. (at the counter Gunther starts to cry and runs into the back room) Ah, and no offence to everybody who ah, still works here, you have no idea how good it feels to say that as of this moment I will never have to make coffee again.

content.description: Rachel’s new job, Rachel’s boss is telling her what to do.

content.speaker: Rachel’s Boss
content.text: Now Mr. Kaplan Sr. likes his coffee strong, so your gonna use two bags instead of one, see. Now pay attention, ‘cause this part’s tricky, see some people use filters just once.

content.description: The hallway between the apartments, Ross is bringing Sarah to Joey and Chandler’s.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I’m, I’m sorry you didn’t get to go to Spacecamp, and I’m hoping that maybe somehow, this may make up for it. Presenting Sarah Tuttle’s Private Very Special Spacecamp!! (opens the door and Chandler and Joey jump up, their apartment is decorated like outer space, one of the leather chairs is covered in tinfoil.)

content.speaker: Sarah
content.text: Really Mr. Geller, you don’t have to do this.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh come on! Here we go! (picks her up and puts her in the chair) Stand by for mission countdown!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Ten , ten.., nine , nine, nine…, eight , eight, eight… (Chandler hits him in the back of the head) Okay, Blast off!

(They start shaking the chair likes it’s flying into outer space. Ross picks up a soccer ball and starts spinning it in his hand and runs around the chair beeping like a satellite. Chandler also starts running around the chair and saying…)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I’m an alien. I’m an alien.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Oh no! An asteroid! (throws the soccer ball off the back of Joey’s head.)
(The camera zooms in on Sarah and she has a big smile on her face.)
